newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Jakarta call money volatile, liquidity tight.
newsitem.headline: Jakarta call money volatile, liquidity tight.

text.p: Jakarta call money remained volatile after easing to 35 percent at midday on Monday from 90 percent in the morning, dealers said.
They said liquidity remained tight, with the central bank still absent from the short-term securities (SBPUs) market.
But there was also no auction of central bank certificates (SBIs) on Monday.
A balance of 620 billion rupiah was available to the market from the maturing central bank papers.
One local bank dealer said trading was mainly for short-term money as operators expected the situation to be temporary.
Dealers said the central bank was likely to reverse the policy once the foreign exchange market stabilised.
Money longer than one-week was traded at around 35/40 percent, suggesting the temporary nature of the rates.
The central bank maintained its bilateral rates for SBIs on Monday.

The bank kept its overnight SBIs at 15.0 percent, two-to-four day SBIs at 16.0 percent, one-week at 10.5, two-week at 11.0, one-month at 11.625, three at 11.5, six at 12.125 and one-year at 12.75 percent.
The average overnight interbank rate on Friday was 54.74 percent, compared with 47.22 percent on Thursday.
